awd_titl_txt: A Unified Multi-Stage Approach to Generalized Sequential Decision Making Problems with Covariates
awd_abstract_narration:
Sequential decision making problems are commonly encountered optimization tasks with important modern applications. With rapid advances in data-driven technology, the diverse application examples include online service recommendation for smart phone users, intelligent implementation of intervention plans for medical service, automated financial service processing, and many others. Generally, faced with multiple decision arms, a service provider needs to choose one to be delivered for each upcoming service user, and targets to maximize the overall reward and benefits for all these service users. Furthermore, in this Big Data era, individual user covariates and metrics are often accessible to service providers, which holds great promise in personalized (mobile, medical, or business) service decision making to enhance user reward outcomes. This project will significantly advance the methods and theory for the sequential decision making problems with covariates, and address important questions that are also of interests to multiple statistics-related fields such as computer science, operations research, business analytics, health sciences, and broader machine learning communities. The promising use of personalized service will be promoted through close interdisciplinary collaborations with business and medical research communities. The graduate student supported by this grant will help with statistical theory, programming, and data analytics. 

Under both parametric and nonparametric frameworks, a unified multi-stage approach will be developed to optimally solve a series of generalized sequential decision making problem settings formulated as multi-armed stochastic bandit problems with covariates. In particular, the investigators aim to (1) develop a new algorithm to handle high-dimensional user covariates under assumptions much relaxed from existing work while improving performance; with integration of a class of high-dimensional regression methods and new technical tools for non-i.i.d. samples inherited from the algorithm, establish rigorous finite-time regret analysis and useful statistical properties; (2) propose a new nonparametric framework as the censored bandit problem with covariates and show optimal cumulative regret and flexible use with possibly censored reward response and non-linear decision boundary; (3) study a class of high-dimensional dimension reduction methods to mitigate curse of dimensionality issues in the nonparametric regression settings and significantly extend the use of classical nonparametric methods in high dimensional problems. Both theoretical and empirical studies to incorporate complex covariate structures inspired from business and medical research questions for decision making will create valuable training and research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. The graduate student supported by this grant will help with statistical theory, programming and data analytics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The bandit problem with covariates is a critical area of research in the field of machine learning and statistics. It addresses the challenge of making sequential decisions under uncertainty, where each decision's outcome depends on not only the actions taken but also on the context or covariates associated with those actions. This problem has wide-ranging applications in various domains, including healthcare, finance, and online advertising. 

The bandit problem with covariates involves making decisions to maximize rewards while considering additional information or covariates. Traditional bandit algorithms, mainly designed for low-dimensional settings, struggle to perform optimally in high-dimensional covariate spaces. In this supported project, we proposed a novel algorithm tailored for high-dimensional covariate settings in bandit problems. Our algorithm exhibited adaptive optimal performance, meaning it consistently provided the best theoretically possible reward results across various contexts and scenarios, which is crucial in real-world applications where the environment and covariates can change dynamically.

Additionally, the supported research studied high-dimensional dimension reduction techniques as high-dimensional data often pose challenges in terms of computational complexity and interpretability. We developed new statistical dimension reduction methods that can be applied to analyze survival data and multi-source data. These methods hold the potential for improved predictive analysis and decision-making across diverse domains.

Our research efforts culminated in the publication of 10 peer-reviewed papers in premier journal venues. These publications contribute to the academic community's understanding of bandit problems with covariates, high-dimensional dimension reduction, and their real-world applications.

To facilitate the practical application of our research findings, we have published three open-source software packages on public repositories. These packages are available for practitioners to use freely, enhancing accessibility and adoption of our bandit algorithms and dimension reduction techniques.

As part of our commitment to education, we provided training for eight undergraduate and graduate students, including underrepresented groups, at the University of Delaware to help nurture the next generation researchers in statistics and machine learning.

Our research outcomes have strengthened collaboration with domain scientists in interdisciplinary projects. By applying our developed statistical methods and software, we have studied emerging public health and social issues. These collaborations include projects related to the prevention of post-concussion college athlete injury, long-term diabetes complications, and domestic opioid abuse.

In summary, this research project focused on bandit problems with covariates and high-dimensional dimension reduction has yielded significant outcomes. Our novel algorithm's adaptive optimal performance, coupled with new statistical methods and open-source software, has the potential to impact various fields and improve decision-making in complex, data-rich environments. Our commitment to education and interdisciplinary collaboration underscores the broader societal benefits of this supported research.
